snippet: The Iraqi president nominated the Shiite leader Haider al-Abadi to replace Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who has demanded to remain in power.
abstract: Iraqi lawmakers, under heavy pressure from United States, take significant step by nominating Shiite leader Haider al-Abadi to replace Prime Min Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, widely blamed for country's polarized politics; Maliki angrily rejects move, vowing to fight in courts and perhaps by use of force, throwing Iraq into new uncertainty as it fights onslaught by Islamic State in Iraq and Syria terrorists.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO, ALISSA J. RUBIN and MICHAEL R. GORDON
byline.contributor: Tim Arango reported from Baghdad; Alissa J. Rubin from Dohuk, Iraq; and Michael R. Gordon from Sydney, Australia. Reporting was contributed by Michael D. Shear from Edgartown, Mass.; Rod Nordland from Erbil, Iraq; and Suadad al-Salhy, Omar al-Jawoshy and Ali Hamza from Baghdad.

lead_paragraph: The Iraqi president nominated the Shiite leader Haider al-Abadi to replace Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who has demanded to remain in power.

headline.main: Iraqis Nominate Maliki Successor, Causing Standoff
headline.print_headline: Iraqis Nominate Maliki Successor, Causing Standoff

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
